DOC.HEAD: Lang Plans to Make Ms. an Ad-Free Bimonthly Magazine, Names New Editor
DOC.TEXT: The new owner of Ms. said Wednesday he plans to resume publication of the magazine every other month starting next spring, and named feminist activist and author Robin Morgan as its editor in chief. Dale W. Lang, whose Lang Communications Inc. assumed control of Ms. in mid-October, had previously disclosed that when the magazine resumed publication, it would no longer accept advertising and he reaffirmed that on Wednesday. The magazine, founded in 1972, had been a monthly but was not profitable and had often been at odds with advertisers over its editorial content. Lang had said publishing the magazine without ads would relieve it from ``external pressures'' and enable its editorial staff to concentrate on pursuing issues important to women without concerns about advertiser backlash. The last issue of Ms. magazine was dated November. No specific date was set for resumption of publication as a bimonthly. Lang was unavailable for comment on the latest decisions, but a spokeswoman said that subscribers would soon be getting a letter of explanation from Gloria Steinem, a co-founder of the magazine who remains a consultant to the publication. Spokeswoman Andrea Kaplan said Ms. Steinem would outline the plans for Ms. and offer readers a chance to get issues of Working Woman, Working Mother or similar magazines in the months remaining before Ms. resumes publication. Lang Communications owns Working Woman and Working Mother as well as the teen magazine Sassy and Success, a magazine for entrepreneurs. Ms. Morgan, the new editor, replaces Anne Summers, who had held that post since November 1987 and remains as editor-at-large of the magazine. Ms. Summers had been part of a group including management that bought Ms. and Sassy in July 1988 from the Australia-based media company John Fairfax Ltd. Terms of Lang's acquisition of a controlling interest in that company have not been disclosed. Ms. Morgan has written 12 books, including ``The Demon Lover: On the Sexuality of Terrorism,'' ``Sisterhood is Powerful'' and ``Sisterhood is Global.'' She was a contributing editor to Ms. from 1974 to 1987. She also was described as a founder and leader of the feminist movement in the United States and was a creator of the Sisterhood is Global Institute, a feminist research organization. She was said to be unavailable for comment on her new job. Asked why Lang felt a new editor was needed for the magazine, Ms. Kaplan said he felt ``a new editor will have a fresh perspective on the magazine.'' The last issue of Ms. had actress Glenn Close on the cover, but Ms. Kaplan said the new Ms. would no longer rely on celebrity interviews or profiles. ``It's going to be a hard-hitting, journalistic magazine,'' she said. Industry observers have said they expect Ms. will scale back its circulation base of 550,000 when it resumes publication.
